channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: 4 Weeks Out, Senate Control Hangs in the Balance in Tumultuous Midterms
item.description: The G.O.P. claimed the momentum in the spring. Then the overturning of Roe v. Wade galvanized Democrats. As the momentum shifts again, the final stretch of the 2022 midterms defies predictability.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher, Reid J. Epstein and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Republicans are bullish on taking the House in November, but the Senate is up for grabs.

item.title: Arizona Governor Candidates Speak, and More Campaign News From the Sunday Shows
item.description: Katie Hobbs and Kari Lake were interviewed back-to-back on CBS, Stacey Abrams spoke on Fox News and Republicans stuck with Herschel Walker despite reports that he had paid for an abortion.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katie Hobbs, the Democratic nominee for governor in Arizona, at a voter registration event last month in Tempe.

item.title: 24 Hours in the Metaverse Version of Facebook Was Surprisingly Fun
item.description: Every hour of the day and night with the gamers, parents, insomniacs, preteens and aspiring comedians who are the earliest adopters of the immersive, three-dimensional internet that Mark Zuckerberg has bet the future of his company on.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill
item.media:credit: Brian Finke for The New York Times

item.title: How California’s Bullet Train Went Off the Rails
item.description: America’s first experiment with high-speed rail has become a multi-billion-dollar nightmare. Political compromises created a project so expensive that almost no one knows how it can be built as originally envisioned.
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.media:credit: Ryan Young for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction of the California high-speed rail system is costing about $1.8 million a day, according to projections widely used by engineers and project managers.

item.title: An American in Ukraine Finds the War He’s Been Searching For
item.description: For an unconventional former Marine colonel, Ukraine represents the morally just war that eluded him his entire career. But how much can he and his military start-up help?
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Milburn, founder of The Mozart Group, with Richie, a rescued mutt who has become the group’s mascot.

item.title: As Ukraine Forces Press Offensive, Front Line Is Shifting Fast
item.description: Evidence of killings and torture is discovered in a forest camp outside the village of Borova as Ukrainian soldiers recapture territory.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

item.title: Harvey Weinstein Sex Crimes Trial to Begin Monday in Los Angeles
item.description: The former movie producer was already convicted in New York, but his Los Angeles trial could be pivotal if he wins an appeal in the first case.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:description: Harvey Weinstein, who was convicted of rape and criminal sexual assault in New York in 2020, will face a new trial for similar charges in California this week.

item.title: Do You Have Questions About the Social Security COLA? We Want to Hear From You
item.description: Reporters and editors working on our coverage of Social Security will find the answers.

item.title: Aumenta el COLA de la Seguridad Social en EE.UU.: ¿qué debes saber?
item.description: La inflación determina el ajuste a las prestaciones anuales, conocidas con el acrónimo COLA, para los estadounidenses jubilados. Se espera que el aumento para este año, que se conocerá el jueves, sea significativo.
item.dc:creator: Mark Miller

item.title: The West Has a Migration Crisis. Why Does Rwanda Want to Help?
item.description: The small African nation has positioned itself as an altruistic partner of wealthier countries seeking to curb migration. But experts say Rwanda’s human rights record makes it no refuge for asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Emergency Transit Mechanism Center in Gashora, Rwanda, houses African refugees awaiting asylum or resettlement elsewhere.

item.title: Judge Narrows Trial of Analyst Who Gathered Steele Dossier Claims About Trump
item.description: Matters deemed tangential to the charges of making false statements, including a notorious and uncorroborated rumor of a sex tape, will be excluded from the case.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel/The New York Times
item.media:description: Igor Danchenko, a Russia analyst who gathered the rumors for the Steele dossier.

item.title: ‘Eye of Sauron’: The Dazzling Solar Tower in the Israeli Desert
item.description: Looming over a remote village in the Negev, the Ashalim solar plant is, for some, a marvel of green technology. For others, it’s a boondoggle and an eyesore.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Amit Elkayam

item.title: The Exploitive Anti-Blackness of Kanye West
item.description: By wearing a “White Lives Matter” shirt, Kanye West gave white supremacists a boost.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: The Failed Quest for Community Mental Health Centers in the U.S.
item.description: America has neglected people with serious mental illnesses for far too long.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Animation by Xander Opiyo. Photographs from Getty Images

item.title: Joe Biden Knows How to Use Donald Trump
item.description: A lot of politicians would have vied with Trump to make the election about them.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein

item.title: What if Burnout Is Less About Work and More About Isolation?
item.description: Feeling burned out? Call your friends. Our real problem may be isolation.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren

item.title: Chelsea Manning: ‘I’m Still Bound to Secrecy’
item.description: Five years after her release from prison, Chelsea Manning is still fighting to tell her story.
item.dc:creator: Chelsea Manning
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Lost Friend on My Mind
item.description: Paul disappeared years ago. Yet I see him everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Ellingson

item.title: From Moscow to Tehran, a Crisis of Illiberalism
item.description: The liberal West is in trouble, but its rivals still aren’t ready to supplant it.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house used by Russian forces in the village of Kamyanka, Ukraine.

item.title: Mismanagement and ‘Monster Trains’ Have Wrecked American Rail
item.description: Decades of cost-cutting takes a toll.
item.dc:creator: Justin Roczniak
item.media:credit: Universal Images Group via Getty Images

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Search for Intelligent Life Is About to Get a Lot More Interesting’
item.description: There are an estimated 100 billion galaxies in the universe, home to an unimaginable abundance of planets. And now there are new ways to spot signs of life on them.
item.dc:creator: Jon Gertner, Tally Abecassis, Marion Lozano, John Woo, Dan Farrell and Sharon Kearney

item.title: Talk of ‘Civil War’ Flares Online and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

item.title: Revisiting Baldwin vs. Buckley
item.description: Nicholas Buccola talks about “The Fire Is Upon Us,” and Lydia Millet discusses “The Children’s Bible.”
item.media:credit: From left: Dave Pickoff/Associated Press; Associated Press
item.media:description: The 1965 debate between James Baldwin and William F. Buckley Jr. at the Cambridge Union was a crucial battle in the fight over civil rights.

item.title: Tell Us: What Questions About Climate Change Can We Answer?
item.description: There is no question too basic, or too big. Your suggestions will be used to help guide the Times’s climate coverage.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The First Interview With Anna Sorokin After Her Release From Jail
item.description: In a late-night interview in her new Manhattan apartment, the fake heiress discussed her big plans, possible deportation and the glam potential of an ankle monitor.
item.dc:creator: Emily Palmer
item.media:credit: Ben Rayner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Sorokin shortly after beginning her house arrest in the East Village.

item.title: Greece Tries Stationing Police on Campus, and Students Fight Back
item.description: For decades, law enforcement was rarely allowed on university grounds. Critics say that putting officers there is part of a slide toward authoritarianism.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Officers used tear gas in Athens last month to disperse students protesting the newly established university police force.

item.title: Streaming Services Want to Fill the Family Movie Void
item.description: With theatrical releases way down, the streaming giants have been pumping out multigenerational fare, including a number of live-action films.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling

item.title: St. Louis Cardinals Eliminated by Philadelphia Phillies in Wild-Card Round
item.description: With the Phillies topping the Cardinals in the wild-card round, Albert Pujols and Yadier Molina have likely played their final game. Cooperstown is waiting.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:description: Albert Pujols was removed for a pinch-runner after singling in the eighth inning on Saturday. He went 2 for 4 in what is expected to be his final game.

item.title: The Joy Workout
item.description: Six research-backed moves to improve your mood
item.dc:creator: Kelly McGonigal

item.title: Gut Healing Is TikTok’s Latest Trend. Does It Work?
item.description: Despite what social media might have you believe, there is no overnight shortcut to better digestive health.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: What is E.M.D.R.? Understanding the Trauma Therapy Practice
item.description: The once-experimental trauma treatment has become increasingly popular. Here’s how the therapy works.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Sophie Park
item.category: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind and Body in the Healing of Trauma (Book)
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: How a Hasidic Wedding in the UAE Went Viral on Instagram
item.description: Levi Duchman and Lea Hadad brought together a diverse swath of guests for an unusual event: a large Hasidic wedding in the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: Levi Duchman and Lea Hadad, who were married on Sept. 14 at the Hilton Abu Dhabi Yas Island, had a guest list of more than 1,500 people including prominent members of the Emirati community. Such religious and cultural diversity is “not typical” for a Hasidic wedding, Rabbi Duchman said.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
